Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: Synthesizing Defensive Symbiosis from a Microbial Perspective
Award.AbstractNarration:
Essentially all plants and animals are colonized by a diverse array of symbiotic microorganisms. For example, 90% of the cells in the human body are bacteria. Some microorganisms may be pathogens that cause disease or death of their hosts while others, such as gut bacteria of animals, may be essential for their nutrition and survival. A growing body of literature suggests that a number of symbiotic microorganisms play a defensive role, protecting their hosts against natural enemies such as parasites, pathogens and herbivores. The goal of this project is to review and synthesize the results of past studies to gain new insights into the underlying mechanisms and ecological consequences of defensive symbiosis. Past research leading to this goal has focused on two distinct groups of defensive symbionts: toxic alkaloid-producing fungal symbionts of grasses that make host plants poisonous to grazing animals and bacterial symbionts of ticks that may exclude pathogens or reduce their transmission. These interactions can provide a strong advantage to hosts, leading to an increase in the prevalence of defensive symbiosis. The major product of this project will be a book on defensive symbiosis that synthesizes previous research in relation to broader areas of research in ecology, microbiology and plant and animal health, and that highlights important areas for future research. A second product will be an open-access database from a 13-year experiment manipulating defensive symbiosis in experimental grasslands.

Defensive symbiosis has significant impacts on our economy, the environment and human health. For example, toxin-producing fungal symbionts of grasses are a serious problem for grazing livestock but provide effective biocontrol against pests in turfgrass systems. Likewise, many arthropods host bacterial symbionts that inhibit pathogen infection or transmission, including important human pathogens, such as the dengue fever virus. In humans, altering our normal microbiota can lead to a number of health problems including disease. In sum, key species in many ecosystems are characterized by defensive symbiosis. The resulting book will provide a widely accessible and comprehensive body of past results, improving our understanding of defensive symbiosis and informing future applications of these interactions. The database will provide research opportunities for students and other scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All plants and animals are colonized by a diverse array of microorganisms. Some of these microbes are pathogens that cause disease or death of their hosts while other microbes provide essential nutrients to their hosts. A growing body of research suggests that other microbes play an important role in protecting their hosts against parasites, pathogens and predators. Thus, these interactions involve at least three different species: the host, the microbe and the enemy of the host. These types of interactions, which I term as defensive symbiosis, represent the focus of this NSF OPUS award.

 My major goal was to write a book on defensive symbiosis that reviews and synthesizes the current state of the field across diverse groups of microbes (viruses, bacteria, fungi), hosts  (insects, marine animals, plants) and mechanisms of defense (chemical toxins, priming of the host immune system). While the book is not yet finished, it is partly written with detailed outlines and accompanying literature in hand for the remaining chapters. The first year of the project was primarily spent reading the literature and compiling a library of several hundred published studies, while the second year was spent writing. I had the assistance of graduate student in Library and Information Science helping to develop the library. In the third year  when I was on sabbatical (with a no-cost extension), I presented a number of talks based on the book, visited with a number of experts in the field and continued to write and edit the book. The major conclusions thus far are that defensive symbioses are widespread in nature and that most appear to be based on microbial production of toxins that protect their host from enemies. Further, in animal systems most defensive symbionts are bacteria while in plant systems most defensive symbionts are fungi.

 A secondary goal of this project was to develop an open-access database from a 13-year experiment that manipulated a defensive symbiont in local grassland communities and to quantify how the diversity and succession of the vegetation was altered by symbiosis. This database was compiled in the first year and analyses and initial writing were done in year two. A manuscript presenting the results of the analyses is close to submission for publication. Once the manuscript is accepted for publication, I will submit the database to the journal, Ecological Archives, where it will be freely available to other researchers and students. This project has been in collaboration with three researchers at other universities and institutions, including a recent PhD student, a faculty member at an US institution and the director of a European institute.     

Defensive symbioses have important implications for our agricultural economy, the environment and human health. For example, many pasture grasses are infected by symbiotic fungi that produce toxins protecting grasses against insect pests but that are also harmful to grazing livestock. Plant breeders have developed symbiotic grass varieties where the chemical toxins have been modified to minimize harm to animals and maximize resistance to insects. With respect to human health, increasing use of probiotics that alter bacterial communities of the gut help deter infections by more dangerous pathogens. Similarly, a chemical toxin produced by symbiotic fungi infecting yew trees has proven to be a highly effective drug for treating human cancer. The results of the book and database will help illustrate how defensive symbiosis affects host health and provide directions for future applications.
